item.title: U.S. Military Plane Crashes in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: An airplane used for midair refueling over Afghanistan crashed soon after taking off on Friday from the Manas airport, according to an American official.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Dell Products Make Their Way, Circuitously, to Syria
item.description: A company in Dubai owned by a Saudi prince bought computer equipment from Dell that ended up in Syria despite trade sanctions, documents show.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON

item.title: Last South Koreans Leave Industrial Park in North
item.description: With the workers’ departure, the joint industrial complex in Kaesong was emptied out for the first time since it began operating in late 2004.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Mortars Hit Damascus Airport
item.description: Syrian rebels fire two mortar shells at Damascus International Airport outside the capital on Friday, state news media reported.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA, RICK GLADSTONE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Currents: Digital Mess Demands a Spring Scrub
item.description: Duplicate photos, digital to-do lists and a desktop that disappoints are all signs that you need to give your online possessions a spring cleaning.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: India Ink: In China-India Border Battle, Some Echoes of Run-Up to 1962 War
item.description: Just as in the years before the 1962 war, India’s Congress Party’s response is restrained.
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER TIMMONS
item.media:description: A part of a 1988 map showing the disputed area along the McMahon line, colored in red, on the eastern sector of the China-India border.

item.title: India Ink: Financially Strapped Bharti Airtel Sells Stake to Qatar
item.description: India’s largest mobile phone company, by subscribers, has a huge debt load and has not turned a profit in Africa.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: Prosecutor in Bhutto Killing is Assassinated
item.description: The prosecutor, Chaudhry Zulfikar Ali, was involved in a case against Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former leader, who faces charges related to Benazir Bhutto’s death.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistani police officials examined the bullet-riddled car of the slain prosecutor Chaudhry Zulfikar Ali after an attack by gunmen in Islamabad on Friday.

item.title: British Independence Party Gains in Local Elections
item.description: The United Kingdom Independence Party, once dismissed by many political leaders, consolidated its position as an emerging force.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Star Power at a Global Women’s Conference
item.description: The Global Women’s Fund has given $100 million in grants. The biggest challenges facing women, its leaders say: sexual violence, economic inequality and reproductive and sexual rights.
item.dc:creator: By LUISITA LOPEZ TORREGROSA
item.media:credit: Jonathon Ziegler/Patrick McMullan.com for Global Fund for Women
item.media:description: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Musimbi Kanyoro, president and chief executive of the Global Fund for Women, at the organization's dinner this week at Cipriani in New York.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 3
item.description: Boston Marathon bombings suspect tells of considering Fourth of July attack; Egypt’s birthrate rises; the European Central Bank cuts its interest rate; two popes in the Vatican; and the fate of Venice’s boy and frog.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health worker explained different contraceptive options at a women's clinic in Cairo.

item.title: Rat Meat Sold as Lamb in China Highlights Fears
item.description: The government’s announcement that the police had arrested traders in eastern China brought to light one of the more alarming cases of tainted food in the country.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: Admissions Anxiety Is Felt Around the World
item.description: What happens when an American family lives overseas and it’s time to apply for college? A writer who specializes in higher education and his daughter begin their search.
item.dc:creator: By TANYA ABRAMS

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Activist Defends Anti-Israel Tweets
item.description: A prominent Egyptian activist issued a defiant response Thursday to critics who argue that her anti-Israel stance should disqualify her from consideration for a major international award.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: As Egypt Birthrate Rises, Population Policy Vanishes
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi has remained silent about the future of the family planning programs put in place by the government of former President Hosni Mubarak.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian women talked with a volunteer at a health clinic in Cairo about contraceptive options.

item.title: A Growing Egypt
item.description: The country’s birthrate has surged to a 20-year high, overwhelming the most populous Arab state’s resources.

item.title: Engineer Arrested in Bangladeshi Building Collapse
item.description: The arrest of the engineer, Abdur Razzaque Khan, was a surprise twist since he was regarded as something of a hero for trying to avert the April 24 disaster.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: 2 Iranian Plotters Convicted
item.description: Two Iranian citizens, whom officials accused of planning to attack Western targets inside Kenya, were found guilty on Thursday by a Kenyan court of terrorism-related charges.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Dozens Die in Gold Mine
item.description: More than 60 miners were killed this week in the Darfur region when the gold mine they were working in collapsed, a police spokesman said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Obama Meets With Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto
item.description: President Obama meets with President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico as both leaders seek to shift attention from security issues to the vast economic relationship between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: President Obama and President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico, center, at the Palacio Nacional in Mexico City for talks on Thursday.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: Coup Is Foiled, Official Says
item.description: Four officials have been arrested in connection with a foiled attempt to overthrow the government of Chad, the country’s state prosecutor announced Thursday.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: Legal Challenge to Vote
item.description: Lawyers for the opposition candidate in the recent presidential election, Henrique Capriles Radonski, on Thursday submitted papers to the Supreme Court challenging the result.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Businessman Sentenced for Selling Fake Bomb Detectors
item.description: A British businessman who sold fake bomb detectors was sentenced to 10 years in prison for fraud on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Lifts Visa Ban on Officials From Myanmar
item.description: Lifting the ban is the latest effort by the Obama administration to reward Myanmar after its president, Thein Sein, began to open the country’s political system and economy in 2011.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: European Bank Cuts Rate, but Signals It Has Limits
item.description: The bank remains unwilling or unable to wield the more powerful weapons that many economists say are needed to jolt Europe out of recession.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: The European Central Bank has cut rates four times since Mario Draghi took over as president in November 2011.
